nested_columns

Source: vignettes/nested_columns.Rmd
nested_columns.Rmd
knitr::opts_chunk$set(warning = FALSE)
library(Radlibrary)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(tidyr)

Some of the fields returned by the ad library API are converted by Radlibrary into list columns or nested tibbles. Here’s an example.

query <- adlib_build_query(ad_reached_countries = "US", 
                           search_terms = "election", 
                           limit = 10, 
                           fields = c('id', 'publisher_platforms', 'demographic_distribution'))
response <- adlib_get(query, token = token)
data <- as_tibble(response)
head(data)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 3
#>   id               publisher_platforms demographic_distribution
#>   <chr>            <list>              <list>                  
#> 1 1000630223885764 <chr [2]>           <NULL>                  
#> 2 391650326107718  <chr [1]>           <NULL>                  
#> 3 252399810350802  <chr [2]>           <tibble [11 × 3]>       
#> 4 494418265486316  <chr [2]>           <tibble [15 × 3]>       
#> 5 720879685957798  <chr [1]>           <tibble [13 × 3]>       
#> 6 667047537682472  <chr [1]>           <tibble [13 × 3]>

This query returns 3 columns. Column is a regular old character vector. Column 2, publisher_platforms, is a list column. Each entry is a list of platforms on which the ad appeared. The third column is itself a tibble.

Both of these nested columns can be unnested using tidyr’s unnest.

data %>% 
  select(-demographic_distribution) %>% 
  unnest(publisher_platforms)
#> # A tibble: 13 × 2
#>    id               publisher_platforms
#>    <chr>            <chr>              
#>  1 1000630223885764 facebook           
#>  2 1000630223885764 messenger          
#>  3 391650326107718  facebook           
#>  4 252399810350802  facebook           
#>  5 252399810350802  instagram          
#>  6 494418265486316  facebook           
#>  7 494418265486316  instagram          
#>  8 720879685957798  facebook           
#>  9 667047537682472  facebook           
#> 10 700309751400663  facebook           
#> 11 7138400909567876 facebook           
#> 12 285499940272858  facebook           
#> 13 1133378034153057 facebook
data %>% 
  select(-publisher_platforms) %>% 
  unnest(demographic_distribution)
#> # A tibble: 75 × 4
#>    id              percentage age   gender
#>    <chr>                <dbl> <chr> <chr> 
#>  1 252399810350802    0.0149  18-24 male  
#>  2 252399810350802    0.00495 18-24 female
#>  3 252399810350802    0.0396  35-44 male  
#>  4 252399810350802    0.0347  25-34 male  
#>  5 252399810350802    0.0891  45-54 male  
#>  6 252399810350802    0.198   55-64 male  
#>  7 252399810350802    0.188   65+   female
#>  8 252399810350802    0.119   55-64 female
#>  9 252399810350802    0.0347  45-54 female
#> 10 252399810350802    0.262   65+   male  
#> # … with 65 more rows

The full set of available fields is documented here. In general, fields of type list<string> are converted to nested lists, while responses of type list<AudienceDistribution> are converted to nested tibbles.

Developed by Colin Fraser, Kyle Shank.
